commodity_name: Agriculture Price Index (2010=100), based on nominal $US commodity prices
definition: The Agriculture price index comprises three sub-indices: Beverages (12.9 percent), Food (61.7 percent), and Raw Materials (25.4 percent).
methodological_notes: The World Bank uses the Laspeyres price index formula in the calculation of its commodity price indices; in this formula, commodity weights from a base time period are used to measure price changes. Relative to other price index formulas, the Laspeyres formula has a tendency to overstate inflation because it does not account for changing demand in the face of price changes. In this case, weights of primary commodities included in the indices are derived based on developing countries' (that is, low- and middle-income countries as defined by the World Bank in June 2006) export values between 2002 and 2004. Underlying commodity prices are collected from a variety of international commodity study groups, government agencies, industry trade journals, and data feed systems. Sources for the trade data are United Nations' Comtrade Database via World Bank WITS system, Food and Agriculture Organization FAOSTAT Database, International Energy Agency Database, BP Statistical Review of World Energy, World Metal Statistics, World Bureau of Metal Statistics and World Bank staff estimates. The index is calculated to a base year of 2010 = 100.

commodity_name: Base Metals Price Index (2010=100), based on nominal $US commodity prices
definition: The Base Metals price index comprises six commodities: Aluminum (32.9 percent), Copper (47.4 percent), Lead (2.2 percent), Nickel (9.9 percent), Tin (2.6 percent), and Zinc (5.0 percent). It is a subset of the Metals and Minerals price index, which includes the same six commodities plus iron ore.
methodological_notes: The World Bank uses the Laspeyres price index formula in the calculation of its commodity price indices; in this formula, commodity weights from a base time period are used to measure price changes. Relative to other price index formulas, the Laspeyres formula has a tendency to overstate inflation because it does not account for changing demand in the face of price changes. In this case, weights of primary commodities included in the indices are derived based on developing countries' (that is, low- and middle-income countries as defined by the World Bank in June 2006) export values between 2002 and 2004. Underlying commodity prices are collected from a variety of international commodity study groups, government agencies, industry trade journals, and data feed systems. Sources for the trade data are United Nations' Comtrade Database via World Bank WITS system, Food and Agriculture Organization FAOSTAT Database, International Energy Agency Database, BP Statistical Review of World Energy, World Metal Statistics, World Bureau of Metal Statistics and World Bank staff estimates. The index is calculated to a base year of 2010 = 100.

The index is calculated to a base year of 2010 = 100. The groundnut oil weight includes groundnuts.

definition: Natural gas index (Laspeyres), average of Europe, US and Japan (LNG), weights based on 5-year average consumption volumes, updated every 5 years, except the 11-year period 1960-70.
methodological_notes: Original Source: World Bank.

commodity_name: Non-Energy Commodities Price Index (2010=100), based on nominal $US commodity prices
definition: The Non-Energy price index comprises three sub-indices: Metals and Minerals (31.6 percent), Agriculture (64.9 percent), and Fertilizer (3.6 percent).
methodological_notes: The World Bank uses the Laspeyres price index formula in the calculation of its commodity price indices; in this formula, commodity weights from a base time period are used to measure price changes. Relative to other price index formulas, the Laspeyres formula has a tendency to overstate inflation because it does not account for changing demand in the face of price changes. In this case, weights of primary commodities included in the indices are derived based on developing countries' (that is, low- and middle-income countries as defined by the World Bank in June 2006) export values between 2002 and 2004. Underlying commodity prices are collected from a variety of international commodity study groups, government agencies, industry trade journals, and data feed systems. Sources for the trade data are United Nations' Comtrade Database via World Bank WITS system, Food and Agriculture Organization FAOSTAT Database, International Energy Agency Database, BP Statistical Review of World Energy, World Metal Statistics, World Bureau of Metal Statistics and World Bank staff estimates. The index is calculated to a base year of 2010 = 100.
